text: Yemen one of the most conservative
countries in the Middle East in this
deeply traditional nation women are
almost invisible and for generations
that had no say in 2011 as the Arab
uprising spread throughout the region
hundreds of thousands of Yemenis came
out in protest surprisingly women were
at the forefront of the demonstrations
which overthrew the former President Ali
Abdullah Saleh and his government one of
those who took part was phases to lay
many she did it behind her family's back
and was ostracized when they found out
we met her back at the square where the
uprising started we lost a lot of people
personally I lost six of my friends who
died and they were dreaming about future
for you a good future for Yemen for
their children for good life for their
families and this is not happened part
of the reason why women took to the
streets here was to help other women
that are voiceless
the reality is women in Yemen lead
restricted lives
the vast majority can't read and write
it is very difficult for women to buy
property and more than half of them are
forced to get married when they're still
very young for the majority of women
nothing much has changed Yemen has been
a male-dominated society for centuries
boys are taught from a very early age
that it's the men who control every
aspect of life here there's a
conservative religious majority and it's
reluctant to see more women in public
life one person trying to change this is
the editor of a leading newspaper she
was also at the forefront of the 2011
demonstrations
life is difficult in Yemen as it is
during transition life is harder than it
was and there are people who don't want
changed
happen for real because their best
interests are threatened by change and
if anyone needs change it's this family
we met Amna her family's desperately
poor and heavily in debt all three of
her daughters were married off before
their 14th birthday she says she had to
do this to pay off her debts
the youngest for just a hundred and
forty pounds we didn't have a choice
we're very poor and my husband is sick
what you want him to do beg in the
street
are you angry at your parents I didn't
want to get married but they made me do
it anyway but they say the conditions
are very difficult for them they don't
have what do you say to them they
shouldn't have done it the men who came
here to marry me and my sisters they
know we're poor and my parents won't do
anything to stop it
all I wanted to do was finish school and
become a doctor for Yemen's human rights
minister stopping child marriage is a
priority many girls they get also marry
in the age of nine ten eleven when they
are very very young and they cannot bear
the responsibility of marriage from the
intercourse so sometimes if they are
fifteen or fourteen they can get
pregnant and some of them may die child
marriage is just one of many challenges
women face here there's a long road
ahead before they see the progress they
demanded during the Arab uprising the
hope is that the next generation of
girls will have a chance for a better
future chai Maithili Oh BBC News Yemen
